Award.AwardTitle: SoCS: Energy Sustainability and Smart Grids: Fostering and Supporting Cultures of Participation in the Energy Landscape of the Future

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The vision for the Smart Grid is to support new ways of producing, transmitting, distributing, and consuming energy to change and improve the sustainability of future energy environments. This represents a unique opportunity for synergy between research in social-computational systems and the Smart Grid application domain. This project will demonstrate that on the one hand, for the Smart Grid effort to live up to its vision and expectations, technological developments are necessary but not sufficient: fostering and supporting changes in human behavior are equally important. On the other hand, social-computational systems face interesting, specific, and unique research questions to cope with the challenges associated with Smart Grids.

The project will design and develop: (a) components of an initial theoretical framework for social-computational systems based on cultures of participation and (b) initial architecture and interaction mechanisms for HYDRA, an open, collaborative, living knowledge environment to foster and support ecologies of different levels of participation. Evaluation in naturalistic settings will provide requirements and guidelines for future developments as a major outcome.

The project will transcend existing technological research by creating prototypes of new socio-technical systems to empower human beings and provide opportunities, incentives, and rewards for changing their behaviors. Collaborations with local technology companies, local governments, and international researchers will ensure the broad impact of our research. Beyond the lessons learned from our specific developments, the theoretical grounding of our research will make our methodologies, components, architectures, requirements, and guidelines applicable to a large number of social-computational systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary impact of this one-year research project has been to contribute to new approaches to sustainable energy use. To this end, this project has:

1) Investigated social/motivational factors and requirements for design

Factors Identified 

Requirements Derived

Effects of feedback type

Daily/weekly feedback and real-time detailed feedback generate the highest savings per household (compared to a monthly bill).

Feedback-induced savings and household participation (at different levels: national, state, city, utility, community)

The total amount of energy saved depends on three factors: (1) average household-level energy savings; (2) likely level of household participation; and (3) higher participation rates with opt-out designs (as opposed to opt-in).

Feedback gadgets alone are unlikely to maximize household energy savings

Most effective forms of feedback include both products (meters, displays, and other devices) and services (compilation of data, targeting and tailoring recommendations, tailoring and contextualizing to consumers).

Motivational elements and program effectiveness

Participation is enhanced with motivational elements, such as goal setting, commitments, competitions, social norms, and non-economic incentives.

Changes in habits, lifestyles, and choices

Most of the energy savings achieved through feedback programs results from changes in behaviors, not investments.

 

2) Refined the underlying theoretical frameworks  including

  1. further developing the concept of cultures of participation providing  insights on ways to foster and support individual and collective participation understanding and rethinking energy use;
  2. a focus on lifelong learning, specifically on self-directed learning, learning on demand, and the integration of living and learning to address issues of energy illiteracy; and
  3. how to employ social production and mass collaboration in peer-support communities to share information and strategies for sustainable practices.

3) Prototyped systems and architectures including the design of symbiotic, knowledge-based systems to empower (rather than replace) humans utilizing the following themes:

Social-Computational Theme

Smart Grids Developments

Balancing between "informate" and automate: designing technology to interact with human behavior, actions, and decision making rather than a sole focus on bypassing them

Smart Grid that includes  human involvement when appropriate; fostering smart communities

Interaction: New models of social and participatory computing

Smart meters for effective visualizations, simulations, and contextualizations

Infrastructure: Human-computer partnerships (single person, small groups, mass interactions)
